headline: Good company, avoid certain teams
pros: I have been working at MathWorks for a decade now. Overall it is a good company with lots of good and smart people. There is a decent work life balance. When working at MathWorks, you have the opportunity to help create something that scientists and engineers will use to make the next big discoveries.
cons:
There are some very bad apples at MathWorks. These are incompetent people, who are in middle management only because they joined the company early on, and MathWorks values loyalty more than competency. Some of these managers suffer from inferiority complex because they can clearly see that they are not as competent as the people they pretend to manage. My manager is one such person. If there is any issue he likes to blame it on others and does not take responsibility of the overall quality of the product or its direction. His people skills are as abyssal as his technical skills. He often talks badly about other people in the team when talking with me and I am sure he badmouths me behind my back.

Even though it is clear that the product that he is managing is going nowhere and is stuck in time MathWorks rewards his loyalty by letting him continue.

He also insults people in team meetings and is blatantly sarcastic. He routinely comes late to one-on-one meetings or skips them altogether and pretends as if nothing happened. His demeanor is aggressive. Some of the things that he is doing may be corporate bullying but complaints from people go unheeded.  As a result of his bad treatment many people have left the team in last few years. I think some people have made this known to the senior management still there is no action. I will leave as soon as I get a good offer.

People interviewing at MathWorks should avoid such teams. If you are observant during the interview and ask the right questions you will be able to figure out if you are interviewing with such a team.

headline: A good company for new graduates

headline: A well managed software company that makes great products
pros:
Top management is very stable, has long term vision, executes well and is very capable. When faced with tough business conditions over the years, they have reacted in rational and thoughtful ways rather than just resorting to layoffs or short-sighted (and ultimately, useless) cost controls I've seen at other firms. They have stayed the course and kept to the plan rather than reacting in panic to quarterly results. A nice change versus public companies that live and die by what Wall St. says. Being privately held allows for a lot more freedom.

MATLAB and Simulink are well known products in their markets. In some markets they are the undisputed champion, in others there is stiff competition. Allows for a mix of pace setting/holding the course for some teams, more of a startup environment for others.

Office environment is nice, for many positions you get your own office with a door that shuts. Those who work in cube farms and build elaborate defense mechanisms against distractions will love this.

Benefits are quite good. Vacation, health, etc are all nice.

Profit sharing takes the place of stock options or other such programs and delivers cash into your bank account rather than useless slips of paper that never vest, or that get underwater.

Managers are generally OK with flexing hours and are not clock-watchers. Some people come in early and leave early, others come in later and leave later. Same for appointments that happen during the day. Nobody tracks if you had to go to the dentist for an hour or run an errand.

The path from doing support (EDG) to working internally is fantastic. You learn the product and the customers, and then put to work internally in another department.

I've never felt pressure to check email or log in outside of working hours on any regular occasion. There have been a few times I've needed to work late or on a weekend, but there was generally a very fine and justifiable reason for doing so, and those occasions are most definitely exceptional and not considered a part of day-to-day operations.
cons:
Telecommuting policy is "there is no telecommuting". If you are the kind of person who doesn't mind commuting, this won't be a con. But Route 9 is godawful at rush hour during school months, as are most other roads that get to Natick -- the Pike, 128, even the surface roads devolve into a traffic Armageddon around rush hour. Management does allow some schedule flexing, but when you add things like getting kids to school, life may not afford such schedule flexing.

Transferring positions within the company isn't very straightforward outside of the EDG route. If you want to switch jobs after doing something for a while, the process can be very tedious.

It's not exactly clear what it takes to get a promotion or raise, aside from going from a fresh college graduate to someone with some experience. There are defined job levels, but there's not a clear set of goals to go from one level to the next level. There's a large pool of people who get to one level and then stay there a long time.

headline: Good place to start or end your career
pros: The healthcare benefits are very competitive. The overall atmosphere is laid back and supportive. The campus is a great working environment with individual offices, decent sized gym,large cafeteria and lots of outside space. In my time there I met very few people that I didn't like. They do a good job hiring intelligent, collaborative and fun people.
cons: It's a good place to start or end your work life but offers little to those who want any sort of career trajectory, which is unusual given it's size. The working from home policy is antiquated and makes no sense - it's a whim of the owner. The non health care perks are a carry over from the days when it was smaller; most people would take higher salaries over cookies, fruit & free breakfast

1) Core values - The company has core values that resonate with mine. This is a company where core values are not just a poster but something that you can see everywhere. Check the list on the company website

headline: Great company, mostly bad/lazy managers
pros: Amazing benefits and perks. It's mostly unheard of to get these kinds of perks. Having worked in both support and business departments I can say they are completely different cultures. You are free to come in whenever you want and leave whenever you want if you are in a non-support role.
cons: Most employees are very lazy and leave for the day way too early. Many managers don't seem to care about their team. Some have no clue what their employees are doing/not doing. Compensation is not really based on performance, but rather meeting sometimes strange company metrics/goals. It is always hard to make improvements as management thinks you don't like current environment and you are against everything they say.

headline: Relaxed workplace with no future!
pros: Relaxed. Free Wed. breakfast. Free Friday cookie. Lots of perks.
cons:
The company still has the mind set of a small company (< 500, in mid nineties) and has a hard time growing into the culture of a mid size company (>3200 in 2015). Middle-management is very slow in motivating engineers or giving them opportunities for growth. This is mostly because there is no competitors (except for open-source, the biggest enemy of MathWorks). 

You get a cozy job with no opportunities for growth. You may work here for a long time and never get promoted because"you're compared against others", a nonsensical alibi given by managers who in most cases are not technical at all!

headline: Great place to work, but missing carrier opportunities
pros:
MathWorks is a high-tech company, where engineering people are really well considered. Decision are often coming from consensus and not from the top without explanation.
MathWorks is serving many high-tech industries and customers, leading to great challenges.
Salary and compensation are good.
Benefit and perks, in France, are OK.
High level management is respectful and open minded.
Very opened company, where employees have access to almost all information. Nothing is hidden.
Privately own, and it privileges the long term vision rather to short term stock evolution.
Company invests on employees and IT.
cons:
There is almost no opportunity to grow here. Company unofficial policy is to let people where they are and gain expertise in their position. So people willing to grow with more responsibilities, or in other business areas will not succeed here.
As every decision requires a consensus, it can take a while before decision is taken, leading to some latency.
The company is not a technical leader, it follows trends rather than creating them.

Great salary, unheard of benefits and perks, and a highly rational workplace. They really care about doing things the right way, for their employees, customers, and community.

headline: Stale
pros: Competitive pay which is automatically raised by 3-4% each year. Challenging product.
cons: All in all, a lot of broken promises, bureaucracy, dysfunctional management and cynicism. Very bare-minimum time off. Paternity leave 5 days (excuse me?) Absolutely no remote work allowed. Period. You should be there, like a slave, even if you just sit at your office debugging. Ridiculous review cycle, which some managers do not follow. Cult of seniority. You are expected to do what you are told by higher-ups (de-facto; on paper Mathworks is a democracy where in fact it is a pure autocracy). Zero promotions. No feedback is heard. Everybody is pretty stuck up, nobody cracks jokes! Oh yes, CEO's idol is Jim Collins - he idolizes Mr. Collins, which quite discredits him in my eyes.

headline: mathworks review

headline: Review for EDG
pros: Good work culture, products that touch many lives. Core values , good work life balance.
cons: EDG in India is quite poor. Students from premiere institutions are recruited and told they can make career in their respective fields, this is not true. Once a fresher joins he/she will come to know there are no choices to make as such. Only 5 departments and no core. Very few openings makes transfer for EDG very difficult. Getting t stuck with support profile is the worst thing that happen flt career that too engineers from top notch institutes. Only few technologies helpful for long term career outside MathWorks. Managers from other departments recruit people from outside even freshers are recruited which sets EDG model for a question. People don't leave because they are left with no choice rather stay in EDG only. During recruitment students are not told truth about the career opportunities.

headline: Application Support Engineer
pros:
NOTE: This review is for the application support engineering role ONLY and does not reflect the rest of the company or other departments.

Pros would include:
- A safe haven for foreign nationals looking for a long term career path and eventual citizenship in the US. They will do all the immigration paper work for you.

-Many social gathering/events, generally positive work environment

-An opportunity to explore other departments within Mathworks and learn the tools
cons:
Your experience in EDG may vary depending on your manager. Some managers are very by-the-book while others are more laid back.

- You're no longer an "engineer". Any notion or aspirations you once had of actually designing something cool is kind of thrown out the window. Instead, the focus lately has been transferring people to the "quality engineering" team where you will be doing software testing once you're done with EDG. To maximize the benefits of a future career path, choose your team wisely. However, most look for an easy opportunity to transfer out without any serious thought or consideration while others are much more definitive about what they want (you’ll see senior EDG members who have been here for 3 years or more in this category). If you’re willing to work a little harder and brush up on C++, joining development instead of QE is a better career path (both pay and experience)

- The company as a whole is obsessed with quantifiable metrics, more so with the EDG group. Tech support cases take more priority over projects for the sake of customer satisfaction. Example: Didn’t contact a customer for more than 1 business day? Send them an email explaining your progress, even if you have no progress to report.  Long weekends are usually followed by putting extra people on tech support for the flood of email cases that comes in. Projects are the key to transferring out of EDG, but the irony is that sometimes tech support over-rules this and you're forced to task-switch.

-A member in EDG is expected to "contribute" to the team however the sudden growth of this department head count has led to a deprivation of any sort of needed contribution. This usually leads to people coming up with very niche/useless "EDG-projects" that have little impact on actually helping anyone. Many meetings will be had and usually nothing will come of it. Ideas spawned by managers might turn into a “pilot project” where they may test a new procedure out. Some of these projects are useful and can benefit the team but it has been noted that a large majority of them just haven’t gone anywhere at all and are eventually killed because the idea was not-so-great to begin with.

- Process. Oh, and a ton of meetings, many of which can be skipped, especially for more senior members of the team.

-Try not to stick around for more than a year and a half in EDG. You’ll eventually have doubts about staying with the company over-all and wanting to do something else – generally, your level of involvement in answering tech support questions will stagnate and you’re encouraged to focus more on career development (picking up projects), however, you’ll still get blind-sided by tasks  in contributing to the EDG team.

headline: Great place to work for.
pros:
1. The company takes it's core values very seriously.
2. They invest in their employees even though they do not offer a competitive pay package.
3. The software they develop is top notch and you are touching lives of many people with their product.
4. Very open work environment. Employees are encouraged to share their feedback about everything to make the company a better place to work for. 
5. Very good work-life balance.
6. Nice gym.
cons:
1. The pay package is less when compared to software companies of same reputation. 
2. Some departments like EDG, there is so much multi-tasking involved with the job.

headline: Good company for a first job - do not stay too long!
pros:
- This is a good place to work if this is your first job out of college (but do not get stuck here!).
- Company has a good process to ramp up new hires.
- Some of the in-house training opportunities are very good. 
- It is easy to have a good work/life balance in most teams.
- Everybody in development gets nice private offices. 
- If you pay attention, you will learn software engineering working here.
- The company purchases books for everyone.
- Work/life balance can be very good.
- Facilities are top notch.
cons:
- Pay scale is 10% to 30% below industry average.
- Bonus structure is not transparent, below industry average, and rigged to favour upper management positions.
- The company hires overqualified people for most positions. 
- It is hard to develop transferable skills in most positions.
- Company is very process-heavy. 
- Previous work experience, education, or training is not valued; all that matters is MathWorks 
tenure. 
- Merit-based career advance is slow to none.
- Lots of pushback and passive aggressiveness from company old timers.
- The core values taught during orientation are only followed by individual contributors; management 
follows them or not depending on the circumstances.
- Everything gets reinvented in-house many times over.
- Too much process: plan on spending about half of your time in meetings.
- No telecommuting allowed.
- Family members not welcome to many of the company party events; what company 
organizes parties with dancing and alcohol but does not allow you to bring 
your significant other?

headline: Quality Engineer
pros: Good environment and talented people in company.
cons: Hiring process does not appear to be great. It is so called systematic  but takes so long to fill up any position and reject candidates for silly reasons.

headline: Great, well respected company and products
pros: This would qualify as one of the great American companies that makes great products and really values its employees. Employees are highly qualified, and the products are widely used and well respected across basically all industries. There are plenty of learning opportunities such as seminars and training sessions available, not just related work but also about fitness, finance, health etc.   Work life balance is amazing
cons: It is a conservative company, and new ideas and features are scrutinized minutely and take some time to come to fruition.

headline: good place to work
pros: It has a good work culture.
cons: It pays very low salary.

headline: Overall it was a nice place to work.
pros: It was a nice work environment and people were friendly. They had good benefits and a casual dress code. The covered parking was nice in the winter time.
cons: They were constantly changes processes and a large number of people had to approve even small changes. Nothing could be done quickly because they needed to collaborate with 5+ other people.

headline: Software Developer
pros:
- Extremely healthy work culture.
- Fast paced development cycle.
cons:
- Conservative growth plan. 
- Expects an employee to spend a fixed number of years in a given position before accredited for their efforts.

headline: Terrific company!
pros:
+ Supportive environment that helps you develop professionally and personally.
+ Competitive salaries and quarterly bonuses.
+ Coworkers are fun, bright, pleasant, professional and genuinely enjoy their work. This all makes for a great work environment!
+ Practically everyone gets a 10' x 10' office with a door - very nice.
cons:
+ Location in Natick is difficult to get to by public transportation; you really need a car.
+ Limited work from home and flex schedule options.

headline: Great company, smart people, growing fast.
pros: Wednesday breakfasts, Friday cookies, team outings, company outings, bright coworkers, opportunities to learn, casual culture, 6 month release cycle.
cons: The company is growing rapidly. Because of this, many projects/problems overlap across teams and I have seen competition between teams to solve problems rather than cooperation amongst them.  The only other (minor) negative is location.

headline: Software Developer
pros:
Very friendly , employee loving company. 
People  believe in doing the right thing - even if it is time consuming. 
Good work life balance. Training is very much part of work - and learning is encouraged.
cons:
For just a software developer - the pay seems to be a little lower than below average - but I guess the other perks like bonuses, profit sharing - would make up for that.

Sometimes can be very relaxed ...

headline: Too much micromanagement in EDG
pros: Modern workplace, nice facilities including gym and offices. Free breakfast on Wednesdays.
cons:
Poor management at EDG. The managers tend to micromanage people and create a kindergarten like atmosphere. EDG is a ruse for them to get Technical support done by highly qualified people and their values have diverged from the company's core values. Work/life balance is screwed up since you have to frequently have to work 12hr days and the hard work you would put in is not appreciated but rather seen as standard expectations. 

None of the managers have technical skills so they frequently try to evade questions by asking the same questions back to people. "What do you think" is the most commonly used phrase here and there is never any logical explanation for anything.

headline: Has its advantages, but certainly in need of improvement
pros:
- Great, intelligent people to work with
- Decent work-life balance (nice to have gym on campus, etc.)
- The company feels "young", which is nice for new graduates
cons:
- Low pay (we shouldn't have to rely on a stakeholder bonus to get a halfway decent salary)
- Management is in general pretty awful
- Too much emphasis on procedures and bureaucracy 
- Difficult to get promoted (not based on merit- my manager even told me I just haven't been here long enough)

headline: Application Support Engineer (Engineering Development Group)
pros: Great entry level position for engineering majors fresh out of school.  You learn a lot about MATLAB/Simulink in this role.  Also gain experience with debugging issues and working with customers.  Most of your co-workers in Engineering Development Group are also fresh out of college, so there is a strong sense of camaraderie and teamwork, as well as opportunities for socialization and forming friendships.  Also, the salary and benefits are quite good (for an entry-level position).
cons: Some (not all) of the Managers tend to get on your case about trivial matters.  Also, the management style in the Engineering Development Group (EDG) is very autocratic.  Thankfully, this is not true about the company as a whole, just the EDG Department specifically.  While the salary/benefits are good by entry-level standards, they are not so great for people with years of work experience.

headline: EDG is not the place you want to be
pros: Good name in the industry, Good compensation, Motivation to move out from EDG. Smart peers
cons: Management in EDG doesn't care about ASE's career development or learning. All they want to do is save their a** and look good in front of higher management. The program is portrayed as one which gives flexibility and freedom to pursue your interests but that is rarely the case. Managers start thrusting some stupid timelines and documents on you and will keep wanting you to do more of Technical Support in the name of "Leadership Qualities".

headline: Great company, fun work atmosphere, intelligent workforce, nice campus
pros: Strong team-building and focus on developing great products/solutions for customers. Nice workplace and intelligent coworkers make this a fun place to work. Private company in charge of own destiny (not shareholder driven)
cons:
Company heavily focuses on internal communications, which is positive, but sometimes leads to missed opportunities to listen to customers. Tendency to take too long to make decisions. 
Strange career development path in many areas of company. Come in at high salary level otherwise you're stuck.

headline: Operations
pros: Great perks, facilities, and people. Everyone has their own individual office and the gym is extremely convenient, affordable, and enjoyable! It's a very stable company with continued growth quarter after quarter.
cons: Unless you are an engineer/developer/manager the pay is behind the industry.

headline: OK company to start or end your carreer
pros:
You have the chance to work with very smart people.
High impact in terms of industry range.
Great facilities and work conditions.
cons:
No industry competitors - because there is partially no competitors higher management have no reason to make any house cleaning, be more efficient or work towards leaning workflows.

With some exceptions mid-management is poor. It's not about your management skills is about how long are you in the company. That makes a huge difference in terms of getting the best resources, review and support.

Very conservative in what regards changes. Very process oriented and slow moving - when something new is to be proposed with the objective of improving quality of work, it has to be reviewed so intensively that most people just give up and don't bother anymore. I think too many great ideas not even come to the surface because of people not believing it will ever happen.

Unclear review criteria.

Hard to be promoted or get decent salaries increases.

headline: No growth opportunities in India
pros: Less pressure. A lot of trainings in the Engineering Development Group. A chance to go to Boston to attend the orientation program.
cons: Very less opportunities in India. There is no transparency in the departments to transfer into. People have to stay in the Engineering Development Group for many years till they find a transfer department due to very little options.

headline: MATLAB
pros:
Good work-life balance

Can grow really fast if you are working in the right team
cons: Paygrade is very low compared to other software firms.

headline: Sales
pros: Great work life balance. Highly Qualified leads
cons: Very slow promotion path for employees.

headline: Documentation Senior Team Lead
pros: rational workplace, cares about employees, great work environment, very collaborative
cons: strict work from home policy (maximum 3 days per year), limited flexibility for hours, difficult commute unless you live very close

headline: Overall a fantastic stable, albeit slow, company to work for.
pros: Positive culture; good set of people to work with. Endless, but slow, possibilities if you understand the system, and know how to operate with a positive attitude and lots of patience. Very cool technology that's coveted by engineers developing some of the complex systems in the world. Decent competitive perks, and comparable compensation depending on your role/experience.
cons: As the company has grown over the years, it's gotten harder to navigate the internal processes and systems. Lots of long timers around - both a pro and con - changing mindsets is hard but possible if you have the wherewithal. Thinking out of the box is a rarity; conformity is valued - mavericks are sometimes tolerated if they add value without rocking the boat too much.

headline: Sales Operations
pros: Good work life balance here
cons: Difficult place to build a career

headline: Software Quality Engineer
pros: Great flexibility such as outing, personal training development, flexible work schedule.
cons:
Not good work life balance,
Big company, so much of the time is lost in meetings
Little growth, Low Competitive pay

headline: Some development jobs are to be avoided
pros:
Nice perks like free cookies on Fridays and Wednesday breakfasts.
Beautiful building
Your own office.
Great, smart colleagues
cons:
Some development directors regularly put down and treat subordinates poorly
They get away with it, because there is a culture of looking the other way when they act this way.
This is not across the board, but there are some VERY bad apples, and it really affects the whole management chain, because the managers are walking on pins and needles trying to not rile up these directors who have short triggers.
They preach respect and invest, but that seems to only hold true at the lower levels, and it is not true for how management treats its reports.

headline: Two stars for the Natick work culture. Bangalore culture is horrible.
pros: Good work. Good learning. Few brilliant and smart people. That's it! I am writing this because I have to write at least 20 words as Pros.
cons:
Partiality - Lick your manager, you will be promoted.
Pay - Will pay you way below standards, accept it or get lost.
HR - Standard dialogues are read every time from a document. Should have memorized by now.

headline: Web Application Engineer Intern
pros: Good culture, nice environment, nice management
cons: No work from home option

headline: Sales
pros: As the company was growing it was a great place to work.  Now, it is a monopoly that operates like one in a vacuum.  The benefits are great if you can tolerate the culture.
cons: The owner is a total control freak that is awkward with people.  He never talks to customers and rarely appreciates any feedback from employees.  The business model is 10 years out-dated.  Every decision has to be made by the owner or CFO without any outside advice.  What company that is $800 million refuses to have an outside board?  Ask yourself why you haven't heard of a 30 year old software company with 3500 people.  Sales people are having their compensation cut and managers are expected to do what they're told.  If something is challenged - you are a pariah.  The culture is miserable, people could do much better.  There are a handful of people that have made it financially, otherwise everybody else should expect to be underpaid.

headline: Awesome work life balance and great perks!
pros:
- Work life balance
- Great culture
- Great perks
- Awesome campus
- Great cafe!  and gym
- You get your own office space.
cons:
- Sometimes things are slow moving in the organization
- Some teams are very picky about standards and processes. Some flexibility required.

headline: Release Engineer
pros: Good CEO, company cares about the employees. summer/winter celebrations. Free cookies, breakfast. You need to be in the right team to have a good work life balance.
cons: Company does not hire managers from outside, they just promote candidates to mangerial level. They just don't know how to manage their reportees. Very few people managers are good at their job. Release engineers are jokers in the company. Managers just hire  fresh graduates who does not know any thing about the position and make them just act as Quality Analyst. No career path. Crazy work hours is a norm in the team. So called Mangers think they know everything and they just don't care about the people under them.

headline: Good working place
pros: Nice working place and great facilities.
cons: Not competitive pay than tech company, small rewards.

headline: Nano-managed company kills any motivation to think
pros:
Company structure is well suited for the US market, optimized sales force and processes
Life is indeed relatively good as long as you're in Natick
cons:
One fit's all mentality, what works in the US works everywhere
Litterally every decision has to be escalated to management, no room for own ideas. These are either killed or sold as the manager's ideas.
Focus on "improvements" is technically harassing people for any error that happened. Only people without any initiatives can flourish here! 1984 style observation and mistrust from above.
No work from home for individual contributors, only for managers.

headline: OK company to work for
pros: good work life balance if you love to be mediocre
cons: However, striving for excellence need not be rewarded too

headline: One of the best companies to work for in the Boston area
pros:
- Interesting work, great co-workers
- Very good work-life balance
cons: - Promotions, senior positions hard to come by

headline: Application Engineer
pros: Energetic, collaborative, and challenging work environment with a good work life balance.  MathWorks really cares about their culture and taking care of their employees
cons: If you are a promotion seeker, MathWorks has a fairly flat, well compensated structure.  So jumping from promotion to promotion is not likely.

headline: Good place for new graduates
pros:
-Lots of learning and leadership opportunities
-Good work life balance
-Individual office rather than cubicles
-Job security
cons: -Average compensation compared to other companies

headline: Application Engineer
pros: Awesome job with lots of flexibility around the stuff you get to work on. Many learning and personal development opportunities.
cons: In different teams the workload can be heavy and the travel extensive.

headline: good
pros:
good exposure
programming skills
c and C++
cons:
find difficulty in time management
should overcome

headline: Best company to work for if you recently gradate with a PhD
pros:
Very flexible working environment - no strict working hour or location, free to work from home if needed and etc. 
Very friendly workforce - people are easy to work with and willing to help; you can phone a senior manager directly asking about coding issues anytime; 
impactful product - pushing the automation tools to a new boundary; it's always cool to work with MATLAB/Simulink. 
Plus, very stable company with very few competitors - great job security in a long run
Plus plus, you have your own office!
cons: Salary is not as competitive as some other big names, but it's acceptable (~$10K different per year).

headline: Great company, however some teams lack leadership
pros: Great company led by an upper management that has a great vision and strives to create a rational workplace.
cons: Some teams lack leadership. Such small pockets of irrational workplace don't get visibility.

headline: Software Engineer
pros:
Excellent collaborative work culture. Great Work Life balance.
Lot of trainings, good for career development
cons: Very low compensation as compared to other companies. WFH is not encouraged.

headline: interview
pros: Very good process in interview
cons: short time and need to use webcam

headline: Very good company atmosphere
pros:
Managers and co-workers are very friendly.
Everyone has its own office.
Hardware condition of the company is very good.
Working hours are very flexible.
cons:
Payment is not quite high compared to some other big IT companies.
Full time opening is very limited.

headline: Great place to work for.
pros: The people I worked with there are all very clever and motivated. It was a fantastic environment to work in.
cons: Ever so slightly bureaucratic. Sometimes, only sometimes, something needs to go through layers of management to get approved. But most of the times there is good freedom.

headline: Great place to work and learn.
pros:
A great place to work and learn.
Every day in MathWorks is a learning experience.
The exposure you get working here is outstanding.
cons:
The growth is very slow.
The Indian management is very bossy.
The company is slowly becoming highly sales driven, technical people are not valued as much.

headline: Comfortable place to work
pros: There are lots of smart people around, and you get to see interesting projects that customers are doing with the products.
cons: Change can be difficult, as the process driven environment can be quite rigid.  This means decisions are deliberate, but good ideas get passed up.

headline: Not as advertised
pros:
Work with smart people
Challenging, exciting work that varies day to day
Many opportunists to get "training" 
You do not have to decide on a career until after you work here for a while, so there is flexibility 
Career opportunities, though not as many as advertised during the hiring process, they are still there.
cons:
Management for the "Engineering Development Group" should not be managing a development group. They are basically technical support managers, and generally good at that, but do not have any clear mandate to focus at all on the non-support side of this group. This is clear as they continually make decisions that sacrifice engineers long term career development at MathWorks for short term technical support goals.  

The work culture of the Engineering Development Group is not in line with the principles and values of the rest of the company. The dual demand for our time coupled homework assignments (yes, there is homework in EDG) routinely make working after work hours or on the weekends necessary.

The common complaint for this position is simply that the 50/50 support/project time split that is repeated all throughout the hiring process and at career fairs is simply not true. 70/30 is more accurate.

headline: Quality Engineer
pros: The environment is very good. People are also very nice. Compared to company located in Boston, the location of MathWorks is much better.
cons: MathWorks is a private company, so the salary or bonus may not be as good as big company.

headline: Good
pros: Training is good for the new.
cons: No cons in my opinion

headline: Fantastic place to work
pros:
Growing company.
It's products, MATLAB and Simulink are changing the world.
Great coworkers
cons: the commute is sometimes difficult (route 9)

headline: Great Company to work
pros:
- people
- work culture
- work/ life balance
- interesting work
cons:
- can be slow at times to decide on things 
- no remote work policy

headline: Great company to work for
pros:
Very laid back work environment.
Great location.
Great benefits. 
You get to work with very smart people
cons:
Compensation is way below the market standard. Coupled with the living expenses here in Boston, you aren't going to save much. 
Too many meetings. This leads to slow decision making and also a lot of time wasted. 
Development processes are not very professional. There is hardly any documentation on internal tools. They expect you to just 'know' how to use things. Some times it feels like you are trying to break into an already established group of friends and are finding it hard to get all the inside jokes. 
Lack of consistency in coding standards/practices across the company.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Very flexible and lot of opportunities within organization
cons: Complicated job titles; not as per industry standards

headline: Senior software developer
pros: Great product, good technology and good ambience, plenty of parking. Great work life balance.
cons: Growth very slow, compensation very low.

headline: good company for new graduates
pros: good learning opportunities for junior or senior level.
cons: Advance above senior level is very limited.

headline: Great Company, Slow growth
pros: Great company. High respect for the individual, good salary, great product. Collaborative environment.
cons: The growth is very slow, especially if located in a smaller office. Company is willing to change and evolve but with a very conservative approach.

headline: Powerhouse of intelligence and relationships
pros:
- Fantastic employees: The company has a tough recruitment process, and it shows. Every hire is not just academically brilliant but also a good fit within the collaborative culture.
- Relative transparency: For a private company, MathWorks does a great job of sharing information with its employees through quarterly meetings, an annual global kick off, and weekly team meetings.
- Investment in individuals: Weekly meetings with managers are mandatory, and annual reviews offer opportunity for peer commentary for unbiased performance measurement.
cons:
- Limited opportunities: Unless some of the "old guard" value your opinion, you are expected to do your 8-5 and head home, without much room for new and challenging work.
- Flexibility: In a digital age, a software company that doesn't encourage remote working is both an anomaly and one that could lose its best people to less rigid work hour requirements.

headline: So much unrealized potential
pros: Its a comfortable work environment with minimal stress and good pay as long as you are on the engineering side.  The office is nice and the benefits seem to be on par with similar companies
cons:
Old fashioned management and lazy company culture.  Career growth is based upon time served instead of achievements.  You can be the top performer and not receive a promotion for many years.  Process after process for everything as well.  If you are a remote employee you are scorned.
Management has been in place for a while and there are a lot of older, out of touch managers that are not familiar with modern practices.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Work / life balance easy to manage.
cons: Easily distracted by other engineers around, can't be productive at times.

headline: Good.
pros: Good Professional atmosphere and compensation provided through Perks. Staff are very friendly and helpful.
cons: I would say nothing because it helped me in all the aspects and gave me the professional experience.

headline: Only a 'Best Place to Work' for some - not for people getting hired in trying to innovate
pros: I think MathWorks is a great company for those right out of school or if you have been here a long time. If you do not want to be too stressed at work this is the place for you.
cons: The company rewards longevity over quality of work. If you are used to working hard and getting rewarded for it this is not the place for you. It is difficult to be productive unless you are one of he insiders. Otherwise your 'expertise' is not needed.

headline: Great Company
pros:
Good work and life balance. 
Good atmosphere
cons:
Slow work processing.
Need patience in personal

headline: Nice place to work
pros: Less number of employees, good profile, good extra benefits, working on cutting edge tools
cons: No specific cons . going good as of now. Should continue to focus on increasing the functionality of tools to cater to more industry needs

headline: Supportive work environment, great culture
pros: Maybe it depends on the team, but the group of people that I work with always seem enthusiastic and willing to help. Company really seems to be driven by core values. Flip side to strict work from home policy is that you are not expected to do work at home, which gives great work/life balance.
cons: Work from home policy is very strict, even for long distance commuters. Otherwise, not much negative to say. Process might not be a good fit for some.

headline: Great company for folks that do not want to work that hard.
pros: Easy work environment.  Excellent benifits.
cons: VERY slow to change.  Most of management are original people.  New ideas not really welcomed.  Career path very slow.

headline: Senior Software Engineer
pros: This place is the most rational place I've ever worked. There are no penalties for not being perfect, everyone constantly supports you and moves as a whole towards improving process, product and communication. If you disagree with someone on anything (design, plan, process,) you just say so, give rational reasons why and then work out the best way to moving forward with whatever it is. Combine that with management who actually listen and care about the individuals in the trenches and you have a great place, fun and insane loyalty. Seriously...the CEO is respected and almost idolized. The chief scientist has fanboys at conventions! It's terrific!
cons: If you like fast-paced startups that turn on a dime, this place is not for you. Not all the teams are "slow", but being rational means being careful and looking at all the angles before taking steps towards a plan. The belief is that there is one "right thing" for every problem. They try very hard to find it each time. That can make progress seem sluggish.

headline: Great company
pros:
Really smart people
Great company culture
Feel doing something important
Great upper management
Great product, customers love it
cons:
Limited growth opportunity for some roles
Lots of review slow down innovation

headline: ASE
pros: less work good pay fine
cons: bad culture no growth work hours

headline: Great company and work culture!
pros: training, work balance, benefits, values, invest in their employees
cons: compensation, personal growth for non-technical background

headline: Good company
pros: Treats their employees well, lots of perks, fun company
cons: Salary is not up to par with the market

headline: People-centric
pros: This is a great company to work for. Management is flexible and down to earth. This office is small, friendly, family feel to it and it's very easy to meet and work with colleagues in other countries. They offer a really great work-life balance. This company takes training seriously, and does not hesitate to Invest in employees.
cons: There not much room to advance professionally in your career. Pay could be more competitive.

headline: work life balance
pros: work life balance is the one of the core value
cons: slow career movement if you care

headline: It's a O.K company
pros: CEO is low key and work harder than anyone in the company. Good infrastructure.
cons: Some mid-tier managers became manager because they stayed with company long time, not because of their capability. Interview process is lengthy and official not practical. Some smart people, but many are average since company doesn't offer competitive salaries. They hire people from south west low salary area to save cost. You have to watch out the bonus term. It is not percentage of your base salary. Rapidly hired many people in recent year, but revenue is flat even keep offering products discount.

headline: Great work-life balance!
pros:
-Friendly co-workers
-Laid back vibe
-Good work life balance
-Talented co-workers
cons:
-Limited career growth
-Not so great compensation and benefits

headline: very good working environment
pros: everyone has individual room, even intern
cons: I didn't figure out any cons

headline: Great company to work for, with some quirks
pros: MathWorks management actually follows their core values and mission statements.  It instill this culture as a part of their extensive internal training.  In general, employees are talented and are collaborative.  It offers great benefits and perks.
cons: In Development, the decision making framework is sometimes unclear and sometimes the pace  seems slow.  The annual review process is cumbersome and long, concentrating on 'areas of improvement.'

headline: Excellent place to work.
pros:
Great co-workers from various technical backgrounds.
Relaxed atmosphere.
Neat offices.
Opportunities to evolve your technical skills.
Company values are followed.
Flexible time-off policy.
You feel respected.
cons:
Not very competitive salary.
Work/Life balance can be an issue.

headline: Good place to learn, but high profitability creates political weirdness
pros: Private offices, great tools, many talented colleagues, plenty of opportunities to learn new skills
cons: Quasi-monopoly status of MATLAB makes technical achievement somewhat undervalued/recognized within the company.

headline: Senior software engineer
pros: Great culture, good employee retention
cons: Sometimes slow paced on some groups

headline: Good technology bad management
pros:
Strong tech offering 
Well organized
Clear processes
cons:
Local MD have overstayed his tenure (Stockholm) Need for change as he does not listen to or care about hos staff
Weak growth due to less that optimal pricing and licensmodel strategies
No career development

headline: Great place to work
pros:
Relatively good work culture
Smart, intelligent and innovative colleagues
Huge opportunity to learn and improve your skills
Great place to work
cons:
Modest compensation
Opportunity to move up the ladder are limited and minimal
Years spent at the company are valued more over performance at times

headline: Satisfied
pros: A very stable company with diversified markets. The CEO is highly admired, especially because he established a great company culture. Smart colleagues and good work-life balance.
cons: Somewhat strict spending policy (for example, no business cards issued unless you have a customer-facing role). Very little opportunity for long-term career advancement.

headline: Good and Not so good
pros:
Good location, nice campus and office facilities, free cookies on Fridays and Breakfast on Wednesday, Summer family outing.
Benefits and 401k profit share are good
Good work-life balance
A pleasure to work with nice and very smart colleagues
cons:
1. Beware the annual review process.  The best way to describe it is draconian and demoralizing.  
2. No opportunity to grow or advance.  Careers die here. 
3. You get 3 work at home days so choose carefully!  They are intended to be used for staying home with a sick child, bad weather (hurricane/snow), waiting for a repairman, etc...
4. Weak and uninspiring management.  Lots of cronyism.

headline: It's a great company.
pros: match my background, pay good, environment is good, people are supportive, work under no pressure
cons: sitting too much a day, use brain all day long, too many meetings(waste of time), almost no time for lunch

headline: Amazing People, great work atmosphere, awesome perks
pros: Very friendly and supportive co-workers. Awesome perks. Company really cares about employees. Lot of opportunities for leadership roles. Easy switch to different teams. They are getting bigger every year, so its exciting to be a part of the growth.
cons: Review process is too elaborate. Stakeholder plan is a major part of salary without which salary looks just average.

headline: Great work environment if you are not looking for the quickest pace
pros: Great work/life Balance. Focus on doing the right thing, the right way. Very nice work environment in terms of buildings, gym, etc... This is the opposite of a start-up environment -- it is stable, there is time to think and strategize. Nothing needs to happen now!
cons: Things move slowly at times and you will find a lot of long-time employees who are satisfied with that. If you come from start-up land, be prepared for stability and a more relaxed pace. This may be a con for some.

headline: Quality Engineer
pros: Very friendly environment, lot of room to grow
cons: Laid back releases. Can be quicker

headline: Great learning experience
pros: Most coworkers are knowledgeable, cooperative and welcoming.The company invests in a lot of training in both technical and non technical areas. The managers are understanding and helpful. There is good work life balance, and  very good benefits and compensation.
cons: The company is highly process oriented , and hence changes are slow to take effect. Working from home is generally frowned upon.

headline: Good company, nice people
pros: training opportunities, good benefit, helpful people
cons: less organized to manage employees

headline: Very Nice company to work
pros: Superb work life balance,Great inside enviornment,Best learning enviornment,Nice and talented team members.
cons: Not yet found need to explore

headline: Experienced mature people may find it too rigid
pros: The technical work is interesting.  Lots of opportunities to learn more on the job.  Close-knit work family, with many social events.
cons: Very regimented and process driven.  More time spent in design reviews than in writing code.

headline: There is a reason so many people go back.
pros: Great benefits including annual outing in NH with family. Great products, culture and fun place to work. Formal processes/procedures defined, but exceptions are acceptable with reason. Collaborative teams. Excellent work-life balance.
cons: Slow to promote from within. Like most companies, some strong personalities become the squeaky wheel and gets all the attention. Inflexible work from home policy.

headline: Decent job
pros: Good environment, decent pay, lively culture
cons: bureaucratic company, extremely mico-management style

headline: Cannot stay
pros: Good work-life balance, good culture, people are nice
cons: no self-improvement, medium base salary, low bonus, no stock, hard for young professional to stay,  my manager is ego, selfish, extremely bossy, having double standard for senior and new hire, like talker than doer and sucks

headline: Its been wonderful!
pros: Great way to get experience in every department
cons: no room to move up/compensation

headline: A good place to work and live
pros: Good environment and life-work balance.Great working environment. Everyone has an office. People respect and invest in the success of the company and each other. MathWorks is financially very strong… Cons: Overall, the main markets are R&D and education institutes for MATLAB and control design automation for Simulink.
cons: I'm optimistic about the outlook for this company, I'm optimistic about the outlook for this company

headline: Stay for the Cookies, Not for the Career
pros: The CEO is a very down to earth, reasonable person. The Wed breakfast and Friday cookies are a bonus. Most employees are good people.
cons: Core Values aren't followed. Bureaucracy inhibits a lot of common sense decisions. Immediate management is non-existent when needed. There are very few opportunities for career growth. If you're not in Development, you're a second class citizen. Lifers are allowed to perform sub-par work while competent employees are forced to pick up all the slack.

headline: In the business sector, MathWorks is one of the best.
pros:
Great working environment. Everyone has an office. 

People respect and invest in the success of the company and each other. 

MathWorks is financially very strong and stable. For a decade it has been consistently growing.

A lot of interesting ideas and advances in the technology. Every new hire can learn a lot, college grads or veteran developers.

Considering that the main products were created in the 80s and early 90s, it is really amazing that there are still many innovations happening in the products.

Deeply penetrated markets. Well respected in the industry and a lot of loyal customers. 

Good work/life balance.

Good communication with customers. Customers loved the products and they are helping to shape the future of MathWorks.

If you want to find a good example of Jim Collins' book, this is the place. It shines in quite a few areas that Collins has highlighted in his book "Built to last" and "Good to great". For example, the 'cult-like culture' is an intentional results of years of cultivation.
cons:
Overall, the main markets are R&D and education institutes for MATLAB and control design automation for Simulink. These are small and well-established markets. MathWorks products have very strong standing in these markets, but the market itself is not growing rapidly. This means relatively weak salary and slow financial growth for individuals. With the stakeholder bonus, the total income is average in the design automation market. 

Another typical pitfall for tech companies from the 80s is that there is no career growth outside the management track. If you are good in a technical area, you are expected to become a senior team lead (STL) and then a manager. It is impossible to stay in the engineering track. As a result, quite a number of real good engineers have to leave the company to pursue technical advances.

The weak mid-level managers is another result of the same problem. The mid-level managers were good engineers 5-or-10 years ago. They are in a manager role now, but some are weak at leadership skills and  try to play the engineering role by making critical technical decisions and try to squeeze time to do coding works. This is bad for both parties, it discourages the engineers, creates conflicts and even makes it hard for the managers to grow in their management role. 

The engineering levels and management levels were invented when the company was still small and no one has that many years of experiences. They left very few space to grow when the company became big and people became older. As a result it has become harder and harder to get promoted because there is not so many levels to grow and there are so many people who need the promotion. 

Over 10 years ago it was decided that MathWorks will follow 'the Toyota way' and then became a process oriented company. "There is a process for it" has been the trend ever since. For a currently company with 3K employee it feels as if the company were 10x its size. There are a lot of lengthy processes and useless meetings. Mostly because the process were invented by the managers. A lot of people/parties needs to be involved for very trivial issues. Maybe someday the executive team can realize that the Toyota way was born out of Japanese culture for production system and US sofware companies really need to customize it for their own needs.

Over the last few years the company has gradually fell into the pattern of Collins' other book, "how the mighty fall". For example, most teams have lost their focus. (If every team has more than 10 focus areas, is it still appropriate to call it a 'focus'?) Luckily the top executive team seems to be aware of the issues and are improving it.

headline: Work at MathWorks if you value integrity, honesty, technical excellence, and a family feeling
pros: Exciting work and you are at the forefront of technology. Very supporting colleagues. You never feel alone, everybody is there to help you. Great team feeling. It was the best job I ever had.
cons: Harsh winter in Natick. Can't think of anything else.

headline: Great company, lots of impressive perks and most important, a great group of people to work with.
pros: The people are MathWorks greatest asset; very smart, involved and just fun to work with. The perks at the company are excellent.  Great office space, excellent amenities like gym and workout classes,  unlimited beverages, first-rate onsite cafeteria. Work is challenging and engaging. You need to seek out opportunities but they are there. I really enjoy the people I work with which is key to my job satisfaction.
cons: The culture can vary from one part of the organization to another so choose carefully.  Starting salaries can be lower than other places but over time it works out.

headline: Great company with sound principles
pros:
Challenging and exciting environment, full of smart people extremely passionate about their jobs.
The company is based on solid principles, nothing is left to chance: from the internal organization to the development of the software. Possibility of working on different things and acquire domain knowledge from different fields.
cons: After six months I can hardly say there are any cons. Probably the salary (compared to other software companies) is the biggest cons one can expect.

headline: Great culture and work environment
pros: Wonderful benefits, competitive salary, smart co-workers, interesting work assignments, lots of training and professional development opportunities, non-hierarchical / non-bureaucratic structure, two-track structure: technical expert or managerial.
cons: Learning the products requires a lot of time, steep learning curve, some co-workers are a bit introverted given the product type, commute from Boston can be long despite being a "reverse commute"

headline: Superb software company, the least Dilbert-like I've heard of
pros: The company really values everyone's opinions. They know that developers have technical insights that managers won't, and respect devs' comments appropriately. "Rational workplace" is one of the core values, and is very obvious throughout the company: the reasons for decisions are generally public, and even in the exceptional cases managers will be happy to explain in private. MathWorks has a huge concern for software quality and stamping out bugs, with the attitude that everyone can contribute. Developers can be promoted to management but can stay as senior developers with no management responsibilities if they prefer. Salary increases above inflation every year even during the recession.
cons: The company's not keen on part-time working or working from home. They have a lot of processes and practices, some of which are pretty heavyweight: development philosophy is not very "agile".

headline: Well run company ...
pros: The Mathworks is a very well organized software company. I worked there for over four years. The founder is still very active and cares dearly about the company. The company hires a lot of smart graduates and has a very methodical approach of ramping up these newly hired employees to get them ready to join other parts of the company. All in all, a very well run company. The company pays special attention to training their employees not only on technical matters but also on non-technical matters such as negotiation skills and presentation skills.
cons: There is some level of complacency because of  the lack of a strong competition. Required improvements or features are not put into a product as fast as it could be. Back when I was working at The MathWorks, there was a lot of conflict within a portion of development team, but there did not seem to be a swift action in addressing the conflicts.

headline: Product Marketing Manager Intern
pros: Work life balance, open door policy, flexibility
cons: process driven organization, takes time to drive changes, very conservative

headline: Awesome Company
pros: This is an amazing company that has a lot of very smart people. The products are focused towards engineers and scientists, and I cannot think of too many industries where the impact of these products is not felt.. One thing that really impressed me after joining is the wide variety of ways the company invests in its employees. Training is available for free to employees not only for professional development, but for personal development as well including access to personal finance advisers!  The results of the great company culture are very visible because  I can honestly say that this is the first company in my 15 year career where I have met  so many people who have been here for so long.( 15, 20, 25 years). Leadership is very supportive. I find the culture here very refreshing after spending time in development and consulting in other companies. Great bonus packages, company picnics, not to mention flying the entire company worldwide to new locations for sales kickoffs!
cons:
One of the drawbacks of being in a great company is that there are plenty of people who have been here very long and will always be more experienced than you. You can move laterally and learn new skills and move from one group to another, but moving up may take time.  
Salary is in the market range, but can be considered lower than similar sized companies. This is not an issue for me because I think I have grown enough to recognize the benefits of the whole package than just the salary.

headline: Solid products, but growth is very slow paced
pros:
Good Work culture
Good work
Very popular products, as a developer you will have a feel great to work on products that have a huge impact on lot of customers in Scientific computing.
cons:
Very slow paced
Mediocre salary
Growth is very limited

headline: The Mathworks intern
pros: not matching my background, suitable for software guys
cons: Good working condition, relationship between employees

headline: Reluctant to change
pros: Wonderful, caring, smart people.  Strong culture with well defined values and strategy clearly communicated from the top down.
cons: Very cautious about trying anything new, i.e. never been done at MathWorks.  Prone to analysis paralysis conducting lengthy RCAs before taking next steps -- applies to all functions and departments.  Not very innovative or creative seeing no need to change or listen to best practices from other company experiences.

headline: Software Developer
pros: Great work hours, friendly work culture and brilliant people to work with
cons: There is nothing bad about this company. People and work is great.

headline: Excellent company to be a part of
pros: Innovative and positive atmosphere. Big emphasis on R&D. Extremely loyal and excited client base , to point of being a MATLAB cult.  Successful company, YOY growth since founding.  Flexibility and and excellent work life balance.  Amazing benefits packages and matching program for 401K.  MathWorks invests in its employees for the long term.  Tons of internal training opportunities, committed executive leadership team.  Cookies on Friday! :)
cons: Not a lot of upward mobility within Sales.  No flexibility in pricing and licensing models.  MathWorks has a "my way or the highway" approach to negotiation which will likely cause customers to turn to competitors (they may not otherwise even consider) especially across the millennial workforce. Outdated licensing processes that aren't perceived as cutting edge in software industry.

headline: application support engineer
pros:
- Lots of opportunities to explore
- Great projects and networking opportunities company wide
- Excellent set of engineers from top-notch universities country wide
cons:
- Too process oriented
- Annual review process is arcane and out-dated

headline: Comfortable, process oriented, not a lot of reward for extraordinary work
pros:
- work life balance
- impact of your work, the products
- quality and reliability of projects delivered is high
cons:
- Heavy reliance on process - slows down new ideas
- Low-average reward for star performers - keeps motivation at a low level
- SLLLOOWW career growth

headline: Not a right place to work, One should not join this company
pros: I do not see any good things to mention.............
cons:
Very bad work culture.
Dominating HR.
Indian management is very bad, no support for employees.
No job security.
Core values but of no use.

headline: Good place to start a career
pros: Lots of very smart people to learn from
cons: Low financial compensation, rigid hieararchy

headline: Management by fear
author_position: Cannot Say Since I Still Work Here
pros:
- HQ in Natick seems like a nice place with good intentions
- Nice atmosfear
cons:
- People are threatened by management
- They treat people well when they need you but eliminate you if they don’t need you
- Everyone is too scared to speak up. Even before the exit interview management makes sure people don’t speak up 
- The smart once leave, in sales basically no one stays more than 1-2 years
- MD needs to be diagnoses by medical professional
- Me however, I’m stuck and desperate to find a new job. It is really the badest place I have ever been to

headline: Great place for software engineers
pros: Software engineers are highly respected and regarded at this company. Technical abilities are very important to succeed here.
cons: Career growth seems to be limited especially to get into the business side

headline: Strong and stable organization that's committed to continued success.
pros: Excellent, widely used software,  team-based work environment and sustainable growth strategy
cons: Some in leadership positions appear checked-out and it deflates motivation levels.

headline: Great company to work for
pros:
* Focus on quality - many procedures and steps for making sure we deliver great products
* When things go wrong, there is a process for finding the root cause, so it doesn't happen again
* Good work/life balance
cons:
* Difficult to be promoted - you are competing with many very talented people
* Slow decision making - every angle of a problem is discussed before making a decision
* Natick-based - being closer to Boston would benefit many people

headline: No surprises, you know what you are signing up for.
pros:
Work Life Balance. 
Some very smart people.
Great products and reputation within industry.
cons:
No work from home. 
Tuition Reimbursement is not competitive.

headline: Was great until sr. mgmt 'flipped the bit'
pros:
smart co-workers
healthy business
focus on improved quality will pay dividends.
product helps the world
